 Depends whether or not the bald gene is dominant or recessive and if this is male pattern baldness we are talking about.
 
 Assuming it is male pattern baldness I'll keep my answer to male childern.
 
 My key #1:
 B = dominant bald gene
 b = recessive non-bald gene
 
 In this case your wife has bb.
 You have Bb, because your sibilings do not have the baldness, therefore there must be at least one recessive component.
 
 The outcome is 50% Bb and 50% bb for your kids, meaning half bald half not.
 
 My key #2
 a = recessive bald gene
 A = dominant non-bald gene
 
 In this case your wife has Aa or AA, can't tell because there is no info on your wife's mother.
 You have aa.
 
 The outcome for Aa-aa is 50% split as above.
 However, with the AA-aa combination, 100% of your kids will be non-bald.

I can well believe that pandion cannot answer this question; no one can accurately answer it. We know that baldness, as a genetic condition, is polygenetic (ie it's controlled by multiple genes) and autosomal (the genes [or at least the bulk of them] do not reside on the X or Y chromosomes). Despite being autosomal, people appear statistically slightly more likely to exhibit balness if the trait comes from their mother's side of the family. Even if we knew precisely which genes were involved and which of those genes your kids had, we still cannot tell you the likihood of your children being bald. The chances of the gene combination being expressed in the correct way to cause baldness are dependent on age, hormone levels, stress and probably a variety of other environmental conditions.
